pros: The organisation does important work and does it well - supporting the nursing profession and nurses. On the whole, a friendly place to work and an employer that, on the whole, makes an effort to be ethical and professional. Salaries are good.
cons: The RCN tends to recruit these days for a certain narrow personality type, rather than skills, and tries to shoehorn existing employees into modes of thinking and behaviour. This is all fine and dandy if you are the right type. If not, there is a lack of appreciation of the strength to be found in variety of approach. All the award-winning staff wellness programmes and work-life balance policies look shiny and nice from the outside, but at the coalface this employer can be as inflexible and ruthless as any other. There is a prevailing culture of too many meetings and the expectation for employees to be continually reflecting on, and documenting, their work and 'behavioural competences'. These factors reduce the time we have to actually do our jobs, and many staff are well over their capacity in terms of workload. The RCN is also over-fond of restructuring, so don't expect a settled, stable working environment.

pros:
The RCN is a nice environment to work in and offers excellent opportunities for career development.  Staff can get paid study leave if they are studying for professional qualifications, and the RCN will often contribute to the cost of these.

The organisation offers a range of staff benefits such as pension scheme, a scheme offering discounts on the cost of leisure activities, free eye tests and a cycle to work scheme.  The RCN is a particularly family-friendly organisation, and provides generous annual leave and special leave entitlements, childcare vouchers and enhanced maternity leave entitlement.    There is also an excellent on-site restaurant and a coffee bar.

The RCN has worked very hard over the past few years to increase engagement with staff, and has implemented a wide range of HR policies to underpin the good relationships between management and staff.  In the past year, it has introduced a new corporate brand together with a state-of-the-art recruitment system which can easily be accessed via its website.

Finally, the RCN has won several external awards from organisations such as the CIPD, for example for its Health & Well-Being programme.
cons: Not really a "con" as such, but it would be an advantage to have some understanding of issues affecting nursing, the NHS and healthcare if you work for the RCN.

pros: The salary and holidays are generous, and the rota is organised very fairly, I have flexible working as do most of my colleagues. The best part is being valued as a individual, and having the freedom to shape our departments standards for ourselves. There are lots of opportunities to contribute to focus groups and projects. I'm proud to work for the RCN
cons: Because we are a trade union I think we aren't firm enough when people don't perform. I have to work alongside people who are clearly not up to the job but think they are being bullied (though they never produce any actual evidence of this) when the managers try to performance manage them and the rest of us have to pick up the slack. I think the new General Secretary will help to change some of this - she seems to be genuinely in touch with us at the lower grades and isn't just in it for self glorification.

review_title: Excellent pay and benefits, rapidly modernising organisation
pros:
I have worked at the RCN for over 10 years and there is a very real sense that the organisation is changing and modernising in lots of different ways. New technology is being embraced, there is a multi award-winning wellbeing programme that helps staff manage their health and a range of flexible working options that give excellent work-life balance. 

The pay and benefits are excellent, the annual leave entitlement generous and there are many options for special leave, like days off for moving home. 

Working for the RCN is a real vocation and staff all over the organisation have a real and evident passion for their work, for the organisation and the services it provides. The RCN really makes a difference..
cons: Like any organisation of it's type, the pace of change can sometimes be slow, but there is a real appetite for positive change at the RCN and this is a downside that is certainly being addressed.

pros:
I've been working here for over 6 years and it's a great place to work.

The pay is excellent. Great terms and conditions and great benefits. I took a career break to go travelling for a year and my managers were really supportive of this.

I've had several managers, all of whom have always supported and encouraged me to take on new responsibilities and access new opportunities ; they are really supportive with regards to the progression and development of staff.

Achievements are always celebrated and promoted. I have always been made to feel valued here.

I feel comfortable to voice my opinions to colleagues and managers and feel like any concerns/ideas are always taken on board and listened to/ acted upon.

There is a respectful and friendly ethos amongst staff. 

I really enjoy working for a company who is genuinely passionate about its customers, its aims and its values.
cons: A lot of the job opportunities that come up are in London HQ.

pros:
We support nurses and the nursing families to deliver excellent patient care. That in itself is an incredible feeling.

Employees are committed to supporting and representing nurses and there's a real sense of purpose and job satisfaction. The culture here is focused on getting the best out of people and providing opportunities to enhance personal development and to contribute to the RCN's success.

We work hard and are rewarded for our efforts. Our terms and conditions are pretty amazing and there's lots going on here which means you can come to work and enjoy yourself. Lots of charity fundraising initiatives and health and wellbeing activities. 

Cardiff Gate is a brilliant place to work. I love the people I work with - so much fun to be around!

The RCN is simply a great place to work!
cons: This can be a fast-paced working environment but everyone pitches in to support each other.

job_title: Learning And Development Consultant in London, England
pros:
The RCN is a great place to work!  having worked full time for the RCN for a number of years the organisation is now supporting me to work part time. This is allowing me to do a job that I really enjoy in the RCN, but also understanding and giving me the time to follow my aspirations outside the RCN in a totally different direction. This has given me a fantastic opportunity to  achieve a great balance between the two.
The RCN terms and conditions  are great with competitive pay and holiday entitlements but more importantly they support a healthy work / life balance. There are a whole range of additional benefits and discounts available to staff, policies to  support flexible working arrangements, special leave allowances, comprehensive Health and Well Being programme and board ranging development opportunities to support your development and career aspirations.
cons: I can honestly not think of any cons to working in the RCN.

pros: Café in London is quite nice, good holiday allowance and staff at the lower levels are friendly and welcoming.
cons: If you are a member of the senior management team the pay is probably very good, below that it is nothing to shout about and there is little opportunity for career progression which has led to the organization lacking innovative thinkers and lagging behind other similar institutions. There are inconsistencies in professional roles, competencies and work/life balance across the organization. More time is spent on largely irrelevant internal work processes rather than looking out for the needs of their members. It is a hugely frustrating place to work as forward thinkers are constantly blocked by dull traditionalists who should have been retired many years ago but are clinging on waiting for a tidy pay off. Personally I cannot wait to escape.

review_title: Bullying and jobs for the boys
pros: Lovely staff on the shop floor and on the whole middle management. The feeling that you are for a cause.
cons: A leadership that preach inclusivity and an open door policy but in reality have turned it into an old boys network. Exectives board members reading out emails they have received from staff (I'd assume were meant to be private) in order to belittle them at staff conferences is commonplace and does little to make staff feel that they are equal in their eyes. The 'Dignity Charter' doesn't seem to apply in these circumstances. Get in with the right person and promotion after promotion on the fast track system is a given. Offer up an opinion or ask questions and certain managers will ensure your RCN journey ends there.  If you are female applying for a job in one department for instance, I've heard the RCN isn't the place for you as apparantly as "women don't belong in it". I'll give that department a wide birth then, it obviously requires a reboot.  I wonder how our membership would feel about that sort of language in the workplace? Of course the vast majority of managers and staff are excellent, supportive and offer a wonderful service to our members.  The staff really do care and it's this that makes the RCN a bearable place to work. Talk of transparency, continued training and development, and technology being embraced in previous reviews are unfortunately just words plucked out of the air with no real foundation, scribed I presume by our HR department.  Do real people actually use that language in a proper review?  I'll let you make your mind up but to me they sound more like job adverts than reviews. Hats off to them though for joining Glass Door.  Maybe now they'll get some proper feed back.
